column4: Upstart airline Norse to lease 9 Boeing Dreamliners from AerCap
column5: OSLO, March 29 (Reuters) - Norse Atlantic Airways, a long-haul budget carrier recently formed in Norway, has agreed to lease nine Boeing Dreamliner jets from Irish lessor AerCap Holdings, the two companies said on Monday.
column6: First deliveries will take place ahead of the airline’s maiden flight, scheduled for December 2021, and the order will be completed no later than the end of the first quarter of 2022, Norse said in a statement.
column7: The global airlines industry has experienced heavy losses as the coronavirus pandemic discouraged flying, leaving a glut of used airplanes available for those willing to start new carriers.
column8: The leasing agreement covers six Boeing 787-9 aircraft for a period of about 12 years and three Boeing 787-8 aircraft for around eight years, at “attractive rates and payment terms”, Norse said.
column9: The company was set up by airline industry veterans, including founder and former chief executive of Norwegian Air , Bjoern Kjos, aiming to crack the long-haul discount market.
column10: Norse has met with resistance in the United States where a prominent member of Congress called on the government to deny the carrier a permit to fly. (Reporting by Nora Buli; Editing by Peter Cooney)

column4: AerCap-GECAS deal may hurt aircraft market competition - IATA
column5: PARIS (Reuters) - Aircraft leasing giant AerCap’s acquisition of rival GECAS will reduce competition in the aircraft market, the head of global airline industry body IATA warned on Wednesday.
column6: “We understand that the situation of the leasing companies is difficult,” IATA Director General Alexandre de Juniac told Reuters. “But combining the two to have a big player (in) a very dominant situation is not good news for us.”
column7: The world’s two largest aircraft lessors announced plans last week to combine, with Ireland’s AerCap agreeing to pay more than $30 billion for GECAS, the air finance business of General Electric.
column8: Analysts have said the deal could attract scrutiny from antitrust regulators.
column9: AerCap Chief Executive Aengus Kelly last week dismissed any concerns over concentration, telling Reuters there would be “plenty of competition” in leasing because of the market’s overall size.
column10: AerCap declined to comment on the remarks by de Juniac, who is stepping down from IATA at the end of the month.
column11: “It’s never good news to have a supply chain dominated by a single player,” the former Air France-KLM executive said in the interview. “We hope that it will not mean any increase in leases, which are a very big cost for (airlines).”

column4: AerCap-GECAS tie-up is 'bad news' for airlines, says IATA chief
column5: Aircraft leasing giant AerCap’s (AER.N) acquisition of rival GECAS will reduce competition in the aircraft market, the head of global airline industry body IATA warned on Wednesday.
column6: "We understand that the situation of the leasing companies is difficult," IATA Director General Alexandre de Juniac told Reuters. "But combining the two to have a big player (in) a very dominant situation is not good news for us."
column7: The world’s two largest aircraft lessors announced plans last week to combine, with Ireland’s AerCap agreeing to pay more than $30 billion for GECAS, the air finance business of General Electric (GE.N).
column8: Analysts have said the deal could attract scrutiny from antitrust regulators.
column9: AerCap Chief Executive Aengus Kelly last week dismissed any concerns over concentration, telling Reuters there would be “plenty of competition” in leasing because of the market’s overall size.
column10: AerCap declined to comment on the remarks by de Juniac, who is stepping down from IATA at the end of the month.
column11: "It's never good news to have a supply chain dominated by a single player," the former Air France-KLM (AIRF.PA) executive said in the interview. "We hope that it will not mean any increase in leases, which are a very big cost for (airlines)."

column4: Hard lessons help AerCap boss Kelly rebuild air finance titan
column5: DUBLIN (Reuters) - When Irishman Aengus Kelly got his first job in aircraft leasing in 1996 it was with a firm so down on its luck the American giant General Electric had an option to buy it for one dollar.
column6: Three years earlier, GE had taken over the jewels of ruined Irish leasing empire Guinness Peat Aviation for $1.3 billion and renamed it GECAS, while the discarded rump that hired the young accountant Kelly was left with GPA’s “bad assets.”
column7: On Wednesday, Kelly completed a dramatic 25-year turnaround with a $30 billion acquisition of GECAS by AerCap, the direct corporate descendant of the assets spurned by GE when it rescued the business built by legendary Irish entrepreneur Tony Ryan.
column8: It is a reminder of the risks and sometimes spectacular rewards inherent in a discreet and largely Dublin-based industry that owns 40% of the world’s airline fleets.
column9: The deal marries AerCap, already the world’s largest lessor following earlier acquisitions, with No. 2 GECAS to create an industry titan with more than 2,000 jetliners and relations with most key airlines.
column10: After effectively reuniting the two wings of Ryan’s empire by buying GECAS, Kelly vowed not to let Ireland’s new AerCap-controlled leasing giant suffer the same fate as GPA.
column11: “Those lessons were imprinted into me. You cannot run this business with a short-term liability structure or a balance sheet that is not conservative,” Kelly said in an interview.
column12: “The lessons were hard-learned. I won’t lie to you, but they’ll never be forgotten.”
column13: Known for his focus on managing risk, the 47-year-old Dubliner is a very different character from Ryan, whose highly leveraged bets built but then destroyed a leasing behemoth.
column14: While Ryan’s career was a rollercoaster that saw his fortune destroyed before a punt on budget airline Ryanair rebuilt it, Kelly’s rise has been slow and steady.
column15: His strategy has been to keep the balance sheet strong to swoop on killer deals when times are tough for rivals.
column16: Kelly noted that AerCap had bought GECAS for less than its assets were worth on GE’s balance sheet, a move that GE said would trigger a $3 billion charge.
column17: “No other company in aircraft leasing has ever done an M&A trade below book (value). Aercap has done it four times. Why are we able to do that? Because of our conservative balance sheet, because it puts us into a position to act when times are tough.”
column18: However, several aircraft transactions have been followed by asset writedowns by the buyer. Industry executives warned there was a risk of further pressure on the value of the assets being bought by AerCap as the coronavirus crisis hammers airlines.
column19: “There’s always a risk ... but you price all that in when you do the transaction,” Kelly said.
column20: He also dismissed any concerns over $25 billion of fresh debt, saying AerCap had kept a coveted investment-grade rating.
column21: That still leaves a leasing monolith roughly three times the size of its nearest rival facing questions over its size.
column22: Kelly had himself flagged concerns about growing too big at an Airfinance Journal conference in January last year, when he suggested a fleet of about 2,000 jets would be tricky to run.
column23: On Wednesday, he said he was confident AerCap could manage the volume of business without having to push down the price it charges airlines simply to keep up with the fleet turnover.
column24: A significant number of low-value regional jets in GECAS’ portfolio have been placed until the end of their life, and GECAS has switched a significant number of narrowbodies to freight, he said.
column25: All eyes are now on whether the next tier of lessors will be driven towards further consolidation or press regulators to exact concessions.
column26: After the long road back from predecessor GPA’s downfall, Kelly vaunted AerCap’s credentials as an independent lessor competing with the units of major banks. But other executives said suppliers, airlines and lessors are still digesting the deal.
column27: “It’s a huge market ... There’s plenty of competition out there,” Kelly said. “We’re competing every day against the behemoth of the biggest banks in the world that own aircraft leasing companies.”

column4: AerCap to buy GE's aircraft leasing unit in $30 billion deal
column5: (Reuters) - The world’s two largest aircraft leasing companies are combining to create a new financing giant after Ireland’s AerCap finalised a deal worth more than $30 billion to buy the leasing business of General Electric.
column6: The two companies, which tied the knot on Wednesday after days of speculation surrounding a takeover of GE’s leasing arm GECAS, together control more than 2,000 jets, dwarfing rivals.
column7: The tie-up creates easily the largest buyer of jetliners built by planemakers Airbus AIR.PA and Boeing BA.N and will reshape a global air finance industry that has attracted a flood of capital in recent years as investors look for higher returns.
column8: Shares in both New York-listed companies fell about 6% on Wednesday as AerCap prepared to issue new stock to help finance the transaction and GE disappointed expectations of some investors that it would raise its cash outlook.
column9: The deal comes as the independence of several leasing firms has been brought into question by the coronavirus crisis and could trigger further consolidation, analysts say.
column10: It is the latest move by GE Chief Executive Larry Culp to reduce debt and focus the conglomerate on its industrial core of power, renewable energy, aviation and healthcare.
column11: In a phone interview, Culp said the deal would help GE become better capitalised in line with peers and “significantly” derisk its balance sheet, opening up an array of capital allocation options including higher dividends, share buybacks.
column12: “We’re not declaring victory today, but this is an important step in our transformation,” he told Reuters.
column13: Culp took the reins of the conglomerate in 2018, months after the 129-year-old company dropped out of Wall Street’s blue-chip index following years of dwindling profits.
column14: AerCap Chief Executive Aengus Kelly said the Dublin-based company had acquired its rival for an “attractive” discount to its book value in its second defining transaction in almost a decade, after purchasing U.S.-based ILFC in 2014.
column15: Both deals saw AerCap pounce on solid business rivals whose owners were suffering due to a wider financial crisis. In both cases, the owners took up offers of stakes in the larger AerCap in return for ceding control, betting on an industry recovery.
column17: “This is not about scale or getting bigger for the sake of it,” Kelly told analysts.
column18: The deal to buy GECAS, or GE Capital Aviation Services, includes about $24 billion in cash and $1 billion paid in AerCap notes or cash. It includes 111 million new shares, giving GE a stake of 46% in the AerCap-controlled company.
column19: Culp said the stake would be monetised “overtime” as the aviation industry recovers.
column20: The deal values GECAS at just over $31 billion based on closing AerCap share prices on Tuesday.
column21: GE said it planned to reduce debt by about $30 billion this year using transaction proceeds and existing cash, but announced a $3 billion writedown in connection with the deal.
column22: The deal, which includes the transfer of about 300 helicopters, is expected to close in the fourth quarter of 2021.
column23: Citi and Goldman Sachs have provided AerCap with $24 billion of committed financing for the transaction.
column24: AerCap said the deal would raise its debt to 3.0 times equity but this adjusted ratio would return “rapidly” to a targeted level of 2.7.
column25: Analysts have said the scale of the combined entity, controlling about three times the number of aircraft as its nearest competitor, Dublin-based Avolon, could force AerCap to offload aircraft to meet anti-trust requirements.
column26: The new group will have a mainly Airbus fleet but Kelly expressed support for the troubled Boeing 737 MAX, recently restored to service after an almost two-year safety grounding.
column27: “I wouldn’t bet against Boeing,” he said..
column28: Analysts have said the deal would give the combined group greater bargaining power when buying jets.
column29: Boeing declined comment on the merger. Airbus said it would maintain the good relations it has had with AerCap and GECAS.

column4: General Electric reaffirms 2021 free cash flow outlook
column5: CHICAGO (Reuters) - General Electric Co on Wednesday reiterated its 2021 forecast and announced a deal to sell its aircraft-leasing business to Ireland’s AerCap Holdings NV as part of efforts to pare its debt.
column6: The Boston-based company said it expects to generate $2.5 billion to $4.5 billion in free cash flow this year, with an adjusted earnings of $0.15 to $0.25 per share, reaffirming the guidance it provided in January.
column7: All industrial businesses except non-gas power are projected to book higher cash flow in 2021.
column8: Free-cash flow is closely watched by investors as a sign of the health of GE’s operations and ability to pay down debt.
column9: “We are on a positive trajectory in 2021 as momentum builds across our businesses and we transform to a more focused, simpler, and stronger industrial company,” said Chief Executive Larry Culp.
column10: GE shares are up 31% this year, compared with a 3% advance for the benchmark S&P 500, and have gained about 160% since their May low. They were up 2.3% at $14.32 in pre-market trade.
column11: The gains are being driven by hopes that the worst is over for the company as a recovery in air travel would boost its aviation business, usually its most profitable and most cash-generative segment.
column12: GE said the deal for the aircraft-leasing business, known as GE Capital Aviation Services, or GECAS, is expected to help reduce debt by $30 billion.
column13: It also announced a reverse stock split at a ratio of 1-for-8.

column4: Factbox: AerCap-GECAS plane leasing tie-up would dwarf rivals by fleet
column5: PARIS (Reuters) - Aircraft leasing faces its biggest shake-up in almost a decade, after the top two players AerCap and General Electric’s GECAS announced a $30 billion tie-up.
column6: AerCap’s acquisition of its smaller rival creates an industry titan with 2,608 planes under ownership or management or on order - compared with 856 at next-ranked Avolon’s, according data from aviation consulting firm IBA.
column7: Here is the global ranking of aircraft lessors by fleet:
column8: 1) AerCap: 1,080 aircraft owned or managed, 289 on order; Total 1,369
column9: 2) GECAS: 984 aircraft owned or managed, 255 on order; Total 1,239
column10: 3) Avolon: 593 aircraft owned or managed, 263 on order; Total 856
column11: 4) Air Lease Corp: 410 aircraft owned or managed, 365 on order; Total 775
column12: 5) SMBC Aviation Capital: 469 aircraft owned or managed, 230 on order; Total 699
column13: 6) Nordic Aviation Capital: 504 aircraft owned or managed, 79 on order; Total 583
column14: 7) BBAM: 526 aircraft owned or managed, 0 on order; Total 526
column15: 8) BOC Aviation: 392 aircraft owned or managed, 119 on order; Total 511
column16: 9) ICBC Leasing: 380 aircraft owned or managed, 123 on order; Total 503
column17: 10) Aviation Capital Group: 301 aircraft owned or managed, 65 on order; Total 366
column18: (Source: IBA InsightIQ data covering the current fleet of owned/managed aircraft, coupled with backlogs consistent with identifiable planemaker data as at 8th March 2021. Numbers can differ in some cases from published end-year lessor data).

column4: GE to sell stake in merged entity with AerCap overtime - CEO
column5: CHICAGO (Reuters) - General Electric Co will “over time” sell its stake in a new financing giant, which will be set up following the merger of its aircraft-leasing business with Ireland’s AerCap Holdings NV, the company’s chief executive told Reuters.
column6: The two companies announced a decision on Wednesday to tie the knot. GE will own a 46% stake in the combined entity, which will control more than 2,000 jets, dwarfing rivals.
column7: “We will sell the equity,” CEO Larry Culp said in a phone interview. “But as we shared with investors earlier, will do that overtime.”

column4: Jet leasing shake-up looms as AerCap and GE unit discuss tie-up
column5: PARIS (Reuters) - Aircraft leasing is poised for its biggest shake-up in almost a decade as its top two players, AerCap Holdings and General Electric Co’s GECAS, discuss a deal to forge an industry titan with more than 2,000 jets, people familiar with the matter said on Monday.
column6: Talks over a tie-up follow years of speculation over a sale of GECAS and come as COVID-19 is expected to shift more of the world’s jetliner fleet from the balance sheets of debt-laden airlines into the arms of the $60 billion leasing industry.
column7: Aircraft lessors, who typically rent out aircraft for up to 12 years at a time, already account for about half of deliveries of jets built by Airbus SE and Boeing Co.
column8: The two sides have been in discussions since late last year, one of the sources said. If the negotiations conclude successfully, an all-stock deal could come as early as this week, another of the sources added.
column9: The Wall Street Journal, which first reported the possible deal, said the transaction could be worth $30 billion.
column10: GE said it did not comment on speculation. AerCap did not respond to requests for comment.
column11: New York-listed shares in Ireland’s AerCap ended trading on Monday with a gain of 13.2%. Shares of GE closed up 4.2%, compared with a decline of 0.5% in the S&P 500 Index.
column12: AerCap is the world’s largest owner of commercial aircraft, with 1,080 jets directly on its books or managed on behalf of others. GECAS has 984 aircraft owned or under management, according to UK-based consultancy IBA Group.
column13: The proposed tie-up would mark AerCap’s most ambitious expansion under tenacious Chief Executive Aengus Kelly, who in 2013 struck a deal to buy its largest rival, Los Angeles-based International Lease Finance Corp, after the financial crisis.
column14: It would also involve the latest move by GE Chief Executive Larry Culp to offload businesses and reduce debt since he took the reins of the struggling conglomerate in 2018. GE has already taken steps to reduce its exposure to aircraft financing.
column15: Vertical Research Partners analyst Rob Stallard said the resulting behemoth would be the “mother of all leasing companies.”
column16: However, if a deal goes ahead, its sheer size could attract attention from antitrust regulators because AerCap and GECAS are already almost twice as big in fleet terms as the sector’s third-largest player, Dublin-based Avolon, analysts said.
column17: “The main question mark will be around the antitrust implications,” said Bertrand Grabowski, a former senior aviation banker turned independent adviser.
column18: “One option for AerCap will be to dispose of several hundred airplanes over time to comply with possible antitrust requirements,” he added.
column19: A mega-merger in leasing could also spur further consolidation in a sector that has featured multiple takeovers in recent years.
column20: “They will all be thinking there’s probably going to be more consolidation,” IBA Group President Phil Seymour said of smaller lessors, adding that this was the “natural impact of a down cycle.”
column21: Major leasing companies are eyeing growth as airlines focus on repairing balance sheets wrecked by the drop in air travel during the COVID-19 pandemic, even though vaccines have prompted some talk of recovery.
column22: Singapore bank DBS Group said it expected aircraft lessors would largely emerge stronger from the crisis, but it warned that the weak finances of airlines meant some lessors would face extra problems collecting money from carriers or be forced to accept payment delays.
column23: Kelly last week told investors that the vast majority of AerCap’s customers were paying their bills.

column4: Analysis: Air leasing mega-merger would rebuild ruined Irish empire
column5: PARIS (Reuters) - A tie-up between leasing giants AerCap and General Electric unit GECAS would reshape global air finance and reunite entities torn apart in one of Ireland’s most spectacular corporate collapses three decades ago.
column6: Dublin-based AerCap has confirmed talks with GECAS to combine the leasing industry’s two largest aircraft portfolios in Ireland’s biggest ever corporate acquisition.
column7: “It creates a leasing colossus with 2,000 aircraft under one brand,” said independent industry adviser Bertrand Grabowski.
column8: A deal would reconcile estranged branches of the collapsed leasing empire of the late Irish leasing baron Tony Ryan, which rose to dizzying heights in the 1980s only to be laid low by over-expansion in the wake of the 1991 Gulf War.
column9: In a schism whose reverberations rumbled through the sector for decades, Ryan’s empire was split between U.S.-based GE Capital, which took over prime assets worth $1.3 billion to form GECAS, and a rump eventually acquired by Dutch-based AerCap.
column10: The split is set to be reversed with AerCap, now based in Dublin and already the world’s largest lessor, ready to regain the dominance once occupied by Ryan’s Guinness Peat Aviation.
column11: In between, leasing has evolved from the freewheeling risk-taking of Ryan - who later made a second fortune with Ryanair - to a disciplined asset class, basking in recognition from investors looking for solid returns backed by air travel.
column12: For airlines, the sideshow became so attractive that some strayed beyond the business of transporting passengers to compete with their own lessors. They speculatively ordered extra planes to rent out, before stumbling when markets headed lower.
column13: Most tellingly, as AerCap and GECAS fine-tuned their possible mega-transaction last week, budget carrier Norwegian Air quietly folded its own leasing experiment by cancelling a related order for Airbus jets.
column14: It is not the first time AerCap has taken control of a major competitor under Aengus Kelly, the candid and tenacious CEO who started as an accountant at what was left of GPA.
column15: In 2013, he agreed to buy International Lease Finance Corp, founded by Ryan’s arch rival and fellow leasing pioneer Steven Udvar-Hazy, after it was weakened by the financial crisis.
column16: Much of today’s leasing industry is run from Dublin by GPA veterans. Many lost small fortunes during the company’s downfall and built their reputations on cautious decision-making.
column17: But experts say risks remain in aircraft leasing, which depends on constant access to competitive funding and staying on the right side of a sometimes brutal industry cycle.
column18: “AerCap are doubling down here; it’s a gutsy move and I sense them thinking ‘we’re too big to fail,’ but a few banks have thought the same,” said a senior industry executive.
column19: Another said the new group, representing one-fifth of the world’s leased fleet, would require tough cost cutting.
column20: For AerCap, the crisis delivers a chance to bulk up in an industry that rewards scale, though much will depend on the price it pays for assets and the risk of future writedowns.
column21: For GE, the move would complete an exit from direct involvement in aircraft finance and leave it focusing on GE Aviation, whose jet engines tend to hold their value for longer than airframes.
column22: GECAS has been in focus for years. In 2019, Apollo Global Management worked on an offer worth up to $40 billion.
column23: The Wall Street Journal, which first reported talks with AerCap, pegged the new deal’s value closer to $30 billion, highlighting the current plight of the airline industry.
column24: “In terms of asset value, it’s probably not the best moment for the seller, but it does take advantage of the fact there’s a lot of liquidity,” Grabowski said.
column25: A new entity combining a fifth of all leased jets could help meet new competition from China, one industry executive said.
column26: It would also remove an umbilical cord between GE and GECAS, a captive in-house financier for its engines. GECAS has already started diversifying into jets powered by Rolls-Royce.
column27: Questions remain over reactions of airlines and planemakers.
column28: Airbus and Boeing have relied on a strong leasing industry to keep deliveries flowing during the pandemic, but now face a more powerful buyer.
column29: Regulators could also take a chunk out of the new venture by forcing it to sell planes in a weak market.
column30: Merging the top two players could speed consolidation at the next tier down, with HNA-controlled Avolon sitting in a distant second place and already said to be itching for a move.
column31: The deal may also send a chill through smaller players that flocked to the industry in the past few years looking for promising yields but are ill-equipped to deal with a downturn.
column32: AerCap’s Kelly has described such leasing industry small-fry as “tourist capital.”

column4: AerCap confirms aircraft-leasing business talks with General Electric
column5: (Reuters) - Ireland’s AerCap Holdings NV on Tuesday confirmed ongoing discussions with General Electric Co to acquire its aircraft-leasing business.
column6: The U.S. business, known as GE Capital Aviation Services or GECAS, is one of the world’s biggest jet-leasing companies. It leases passenger aircraft made by companies including Boeing Co and Airbus SE.
column7: Reuters on Monday reported AerCap and General Electric are discussing a deal to forge an industry titan with more than 2,000 jets, citing people familiar with the matter.
column8: AerCap said the outcome of the talks has yet to be determined and there can be no guarantee that an agreement will be reached.
column9: “No further statements will be made by the issuers or the company regarding this matter until the time of the conclusion of those discussions,” the Irish jet leasing company said in a statement.
column10: GE and AerCap, the world’s two largest aircraft lessors, are paving the way for the biggest aircraft leasing shake-up in almost a decade.
column11: This comes as the COVID-19 pandemic is expected to shift more of the world’s fleet from battered airlines to the leasing industry, which already holds around half of Airbus and Boeing deliveries.

column6: The U.S. business, known as GE Capital Aviation Services or GECAS, is one of the world's biggest jet-leasing companies. It leases passenger aircraft made by companies including Boeing Co (BA.N) and Airbus SE (AIR.PA).

column4: ANALYSIS-Leasing deal push evokes past glories to shape aviation's future
column5: A tie-up between leasing giants AerCap (AER.N) and General Electric (GE.N) unit GECAS would reshape global air finance and reunite entities torn apart in one of Ireland’s most spectacular corporate collapses three decades ago.
column6: Dublin-based AerCap has confirmed talks with GECAS to combine the leasing industry’s two largest aircraft portfolios in Ireland’s biggest ever corporate acquisition.
column7: "It creates a leasing colossus with 2,000 aircraft under one brand," said independent industry adviser Bertrand Grabowski.
column8: A deal would reconcile estranged branches of the collapsed leasing empire of the late Irish leasing baron Tony Ryan, which rose to dizzying heights in the 1980s only to be laid low by over-expansion in the wake of the 1991 Gulf War.
column9: In a schism whose reverberations rumbled through the sector for decades, Ryan's empire was split between U.S.-based GE Capital, which took over prime assets worth $1.3 billion to form GECAS, and a rump eventually acquired by Dutch-based AerCap.
column10: The split is set to be reversed with AerCap, now based in Dublin and already the world's largest lessor, ready to regain the dominance once occupied by Ryan's Guinness Peat Aviation.
column11: In between, leasing has evolved from the freewheeling risk-taking of Ryan - who later made a second fortune with Ryanair (RYA.I) - to a disciplined asset class, basking in recognition from investors looking for solid returns backed by air travel.
column12: For airlines, the sideshow became so attractive that some strayed beyond the business of transporting passengers to compete with their own lessors. They speculatively ordered extra planes to rent out, before stumbling when markets headed lower.
column13: Most tellingly, as AerCap and GECAS fine-tuned their possible mega-transaction last week, budget carrier Norwegian Air (NORR.OL) quietly folded its own leasing experiment by cancelling a related order for Airbus jets.
column14: It is not the first time AerCap has taken control of a major competitor under Aengus Kelly, the candid and tenacious CEO who started as an accountant at what was left of GPA.
column15: In 2013, he agreed to buy International Lease Finance Corp, founded by Ryan's arch rival and fellow leasing pioneer Steven Udvar-Hazy, after it was weakened by the financial crisis.
column16: Much of today's leasing industry is run from Dublin by GPA veterans. Many lost small fortunes during the company's downfall and built their reputations on cautious decision-making.
column17: But experts say risks remain in aircraft leasing, which depends on constant access to competitive funding and staying on the right side of a sometimes brutal industry cycle.
column19: "AerCap are doubling down here; it's a gutsy move and I sense them thinking 'we're too big to fail,' but a few banks have thought the same," said a senior industry executive.
column20: Another said the new group, representing one-fifth of the world's leased fleet, would require tough cost cutting.
column21: For AerCap, the crisis delivers a chance to bulk up in an industry that rewards scale, though much will depend on the price it pays for assets and the risk of future writedowns.
column22: For GE, the move would complete an exit from direct involvement in aircraft finance and leave it focusing on GE Aviation, whose jet engines tend to hold their value for longer than airframes.
column23: GECAS has been in focus for years. In 2019, Apollo Global Management (APO.N) worked on an offer worth up to $40 billion.
column24: The Wall Street Journal, which first reported talks with AerCap, pegged the new deal's value closer to $30 billion, highlighting the current plight of the airline industry.
column25: "In terms of asset value, it's probably not the best moment for the seller, but it does take advantage of the fact there's a lot of liquidity," Grabowski said.
column26: A new entity combining a fifth of all leased jets could help meet new competition from China, one industry executive said.
column27: It would also remove an umbilical cord between GE and GECAS, a captive in-house financier for its engines. GECAS has already started diversifying into jets powered by Rolls-Royce (RR.L).
column28: Questions remain over reactions of airlines and planemakers.
column29: Airbus (AIR.PA) and Boeing (BA.N) have relied on a strong leasing industry to keep deliveries flowing during the pandemic, but now face a more powerful buyer.
column30: Regulators could also take a chunk out of the new venture by forcing it to sell planes in a weak market.
column31: Merging the top two players could speed consolidation at the next tier down, with HNA-controlled Avolon sitting in a distant second place and already said to be itching for a move.
column32: The deal may also send a chill through smaller players that flocked to the industry in the past few years looking for promising yields but are ill-equipped to deal with a downturn.
column33: AerCap's Kelly has described such leasing industry small-fry as "tourist capital."

column4: GE nears deal to combine aircraft-leasing unit with AerCap - WSJ
column5: General Electric Co (GE.N) is nearing a $30 billion-plus deal to combine its aircraft-leasing business with Ireland's AerCap Holdings NV (AER.N), the Wall Street Journal reported on Sunday citing people familiar with the matter.

column4: UPDATE 1-Malaysia's AirAsia X assures recovery for lessors in new restructuring proposal
column5: * New proposal with revised terms proposed for aircraft lessors
column6: * Airline says lessors expected to have at least 60% recovery rate
column7: * Calls steep haircut in earlier plan a misinterpretation (Adds comments from BOC Aviation, AerCap and consultant; court order)
column8: KUALA LUMPUR, Feb 21 (Reuters) - Malaysian long-haul budget airline AirAsia X Bhd (AAX) has proposed a separate restructuring programme for its aircraft lessors that aims to tackle their concerns, citing a chance to recover rental losses, a document seen by Reuters shows.
column9: The airline, an affiliate of AirAsia Group, has been trying for months to reconstitute 64.15 billion ringgit ($15.9 billion) of debt into 200 million ringgit of debt. More than a dozen creditors, mostly lessors, had intervened in court to challenge a proposal that would have meant a haircut for them of 99.7%.
column10: The new proposal for lessors is a key step as the airline looks to win creditors’ approval for its restructuring.
column11: The proposal seeks to address lessors’ concerns about their forward commercial agreements and the viability of the airline’s business after recapitalisation, according to the document, which comprises slides describing the plan.
column12: Under the revised proposal, AAX said lessors are expected to recover at least 60% of what they are owed.
column13: A person familiar with the matter said the airline deemed the earlier description of the debt haircut inaccurate as they “excluded returns from ongoing leases”, referring to recovery of rental losses and outstanding debt.
column14: AAX urged lessors to agree to a “pre-packaged lock-up” deal to expedite the restructuring process.
column15: The person, who declined to be named because of the sensitivity of the matter, said the airline wanted to lock in terms of the deal with lessors before convening a creditors meeting to vote on the restructuring.
column16: “(It) balances the needs of creditors and new investors without compromising the financial viability of the business plan,” AAX said in the slides.
column17: AAX did not immediately respond to a request seeking confirmation of the proposal.
column18: Lessors ICBC Leasing, Kayan Aviation, Aviator Capital, Castlelake, Aircastle and Minsheng Financial Leasing did not immediately respond to Reuters’ requests for comment. Macquarie AirFinance, BOC Aviation Ltd and AerCap declined to comment.
column19: The revised restructuring plan comes as the Kuala Lumpur High Court on Friday allowed AAX to convene creditor meetings and vote on its restructuring plan, the Edge Financial Daily reported.
column20: The Edge also reported that the court has separated the airline’s creditors into three categories: airport operator Malaysia Airports Holdings Bhd, planemaker Airbus SE and other creditors. The aircraft lessors, for whom AAX has proposed the new plan, will fall in the last category.
column21: The split could give lessors a bigger say in the talks, as Airbus otherwise accounts for most of the debt AAX wants to restructure.
column22: The court has also ordered AAX to convene separate meetings with its different groups of creditors within six months.
column23: “Lessors have no choice but to go through (with this plan) if they want to recoup their money, however paltry it is,” said Shukor Yusof, head of aviation consultancy Endau Analytics, adding that AAX’s business model needs to be fundamentally reassessed.
column24: BOC Aviation had last year asked the court to dismiss AAX’s restructuring proposal as it ruled out a debt-to-equity swap and gave too much power to Airbus as a creditor. It also said AAX was “hopelessly insolvent.” The airline announced in December plans to raise 500 million ringgit through a rights issue to existing shareholders and a share subscription for new investors after its debt restructuring. ($1 = 4.0380 ringgit) (Reporting by Liz Lee; Editing by Gerry Doyle and Jacqueline Wong)

column4: AerCap cancels 15 MAX jets, urges Airbus and Boeing output cuts
column5: DUBLIN/PARIS (Reuters) - Leasing giant AerCap AER.N said on Wednesday it had cancelled 15 orders for the grounded Boeing BA.N 737 MAX aircraft as it slows the pace of new plane deliveries to weather the coronavirus crisis.
column6: Announcing the cancellations - which leave 80 of the MAX jets still on its order books - the world's largest aircraft owner also called for more production cuts by Boeing and rival Airbus AIR.PA to help balance the jet market.
column7: AerCap, which has deferred dozens more MAX deliveries, said it remains uncertain when the five MAX planes already on lease will return to service, as regulators review changes to the jet after two fatal crashes.
column8: U.S. authorities said last week they expect to give a green light in the “near future”. As a result, AerCap reached agreement with Boeing this month to restructure its order book, it said on Wednesday.
column9: AerCap boss Aengus Kelly called for a further aircraft manufacturing slowdown as he reported a drop in second-quarter net income to $246 million from $331 million a year earlier, amid a global travel slump unleashed by the pandemic.
column10: “I think we’ll see more production cuts both from Boeing and Airbus, to help us get to that equilibrium,” he said during an earnings call with analysts.
column11: “I would be hopeful that tomorrow when Airbus release their results we’ll see another production cut there,” the AerCap CEO said. Airbus declined to comment ahead of its own results announcement on Thursday.
column12: Leasing firms are traditionally conservative about production to preserve the value of their fleets, but the call from the world’s largest lessor puts pressure on Airbus to defend output levels that some analysts consider too high.
column13: AerCap said it was well placed to weather the coronavirus crisis thanks to its $27 billion in unencumbered assets and record-high liquidity including $3 billion in new funding.
column14: “We have begun leasing airplanes again, but it’s almost exclusively focused on the European market,” Kelly said, adding that earlier signs of a U.S. travel rebound had since “run out of steam” amid new virus outbreaks and lockdowns.
column15: Despite European reversals such as renewed British quarantine measures for Spanish arrivals, a recovery is now “well underway” in the region, Kelly said.
column16: “No doubt there will be setbacks, but the willingness and the desire of the consumer to travel is very clear.”

column4: Aircraft lessor AerCap pushes back deliveries of 37 aircraft
column5: (Reuters) - Aircraft leasing giant AerCap Holdings on Tuesday pushed back deliveries of 37 aircraft to 2023 and beyond as it looks to boost liquidity and lower capital spending.
column6: The world’s largest aircraft leasing company, which had previously forecast the deliveries to be between 2021 and 2022, said the rescheduling would help reduce its cash capital expenditures in 2020 and 2021 by a total of about $4.7 billion.
column7: “We expect our cash capital expenditures during these years to decrease further as we continue our discussions with the aircraft manufacturers and our customers. All of the aircraft delivering in 2020 and 2021 have already been placed on long-term leases,” the company said.
column8: The aviation industry is enduring its worst crisis after the coronavirus pandemic crippled most flights, piling pressure on a sector already weakened by the grounding of Boeing Co’s MAX jets.
column9: Earlier this month, the company had warned that it was facing cancellations of 737 MAX leases by some of its own airline customers and reserved the right to reject taking delivery of affected aircraft from Boeing.

column4: Aircraft lessor AerCap boosts liquidity, defers jet deliveries
column5: (Reuters) - Aircraft leasing giant AerCap AER.N said it had boosted liquidity and reduced capital spending for 2020 by postponing jet deliveries, while withdrawing its full-year outlook as the coronavirus crisis batters aviation.
column6: Shares in the world’s largest aircraft leasing company jumped more than 12% after it announced it had $11 billion in liquidity to help ride out the industry’s worst-ever crisis.
column7: Chief Executive Aengus Kelly said AerCap had obtained the deferral of deliveries of dozens of grounded 737 MAX from Boeing BA.N "on competitive terms".
column8: However, AerCap joined other aviation finance firms in raising questions over orders for the jet following a 14-month-old safety ban and a recent halt in production.
column9: AerCap said it was facing cancellations of 737 MAX leases by some of its own airline customers, and reserved the right to reject taking delivery of affected aircraft from Boeing.
column10: “In cases where leases have been cancelled, we have the right to cancel our corresponding orders for delivery of those aircraft,” the company said in a quarterly earnings report on Tuesday.
column11: Deliveries of Boeing’s best-selling model have been halted for over a year, passing the milestone at which buyers can trigger cancellation clauses, as some leasing firms have done.
column12: Still, Kelly told analysts that assuming a successful move by Boeing to recertify the 737 MAX with regulators across the world, the jet would once again see solid demand.
column13: He also said there was demand for the Embraer EMBR3.SA E2 jet after the collapse of a tie-up with Boeing last weekend.
column14: “AerCap is navigating the coronavirus situation as best they can, tapping additional financing and adjusting their risk profile to airlines they believe can sustain the downturn,” Cowen & Co analyst Helane Becker said in a note.
column15: The aviation industry is enduring its worst crisis after the coronavirus pandemic crippled most flights, piling pressure on a sector already weakened by the MAX grounding.
column16: Kelly predicted a limited return to service by European airlines in May, lagging the Chinese market by two to three months, but warned not all global airlines would survive.
column17: “There is no doubt that some airlines will fail because of the crisis,” Kelly told analysts.
column18: There will also be fewer aircraft leasing companies, reversing a flood of capital into the aviation finance market in search of buoyant returns in recent years.
column19: That is despite growing government support for airlines that Kelly said could double to $200 billion worldwide, from around $100 billion already committed in bailouts or public support.
column20: AerCap’s first-quarter net income rose 18% to $276.8 million, driven partly by asset sales.

column4: BRIEF-AerCap CEO Says Deferred Over 60 Aircraft Deliveries - Conf Call
column5: May 5 (Reuters) - AerCap Holdings NV
column6: * CEO SAYS GENERALLY WILL NOT CONVERT DEBT TO EQUITY, EVEN THOUGH HAS AGREED TO DO SO AT NORWEGIAN - CONF CALL
column7: * CEO SAYS BELIEVES THERE WILL BE $200 BILLION OF GOVERNMENT SUPPORT FOR AIRLINES GLOBALLY, HALF OF THIS ALREADY ANNOUNCED - CONF CALL
column8: * AERCAP CEO SAYS BELIEVES VIRGIN AUSTRALIA WILL KEEP MAJORITY OF FLEET
column9: * AERCAP CEO SAYS BELIEVES VAST MAJORITY OF AIRLINES WILL SURVIVE THE CRISIS
column10: * AERCAP CEO SAYS ASSUMING SUCCESSFUL RETURN TO MARKET, BOEING 737 MAX WILL BE IN DEMAND IN FUTURE YEARS
column11: * AERCAP CEO SAYS EUROPEAN AIRLINE CEOS EXPECT LIMITED RETURN TO SERVICE IN MAY
column12: * AERCAP SAYS LEVEL OF ACTIVITY IN CHINA HALF OF WHAT THEY WERE DOING LAST YEAR
column13: * AERCAP CEO SAYS THERE WILL BE FEWER LESSORS IN COMING YEARS
column14: * AECAP CEO SAYS PART OF 2021-22 CAPEX PLANS EXPECTED TO BE DEFERRED
column15: * AERCAP SAYS GOING TO DO A LOT OF UNSECURED FUNDING, MAINTAIN STRONG LIQUIDITY
column16: * AERCAP CEO SAYS AIRBUS WILL CHANGE A220 TO ENSURE STANDARD COCKPIT WITH A320
column17: * AERCAP CEO SAYS THERE IS STILL A MARKET FOR THE EMBRAER E2 JET AFTER COLLAPSE OF BOEING DEAL Further company coverage:

column4: AerCap warns could scrap some Boeing MAX orders, withdraws outlook
column5: May 5 (Reuters) - Aircraft leasing company AerCap Holdings on Tuesday warned it could cancel some Boeing 737 MAX orders and withdrew its full-year outlook amid a slump in travel demand due to the COVID-19 pandemic that has battered business globally.
column6: The world’s largest aircraft leasing company said it had lost some of its Boeing 737 MAX leases and expects additional cancellations by airlines in the future.
column7: “In cases where leases have been cancelled, we have the right to cancel our corresponding orders for delivery of those aircraft,” the company said in a statement.
column8: Last month smaller rival and privately-held Avolon cancelled an order for 75 Boeing 737 MAX planes that were due to be delivered by 2023. (Reporting by Rachit Vats in Bengaluru Editing by Supriya Kurane)

column4: No alternative to grounded Boeing 737 MAX, Aercap CEO says
column5: DUBLIN (Reuters) - There is no alternative to the grounded 737 MAX and it would be "absolutely stupid" for Boeing BA.N to launch a replacement before the next wave of technology a decade from now, the head of one of the world's top aircraft lessors said on Wednesday.
column6: Aengus Kelly, chief executive of Aercap AER.N, which has committed to a fleet of 100 MAX jets, told Reuters in an interview he had spoken to all of the biggest MAX operators in the world and said they still viewed it as a very good plane.
column7: Kelly was speaking after Boeing on Tuesday warned of further delays in returning its grounded 737 MAX airliner to service, with the plane not likely to be cleared by U.S. regulators until the middle of the year.
column8: He said that some of his customers may cancel leases, but that the majority would not and some are keen to order more.
column9: “For people to say this is the end of the MAX, that is absolutely incorrect. These people don’t have much insight,” Kelly said.
column10: He said, however, it was still impossible to say when the MAX might fly again.
column11: “We saw another delay from Boeing last night – I don’t think they know,” he said. “Is July the last delay? Who knows?”
column12: Asked if the MAX might be replaced in the coming years, a move that might undermine the jet’s value, Kelly said it would be absolutely stupid for Boeing to launch a replacement plane before technology allows an additional 15% reduction in fuel burn, something he believes will not happen before 2030.
column13: Kelly said all of the main aviation banks were still willing to lend money against the MAX, but added if that changed, the plane’s valuation would be hit.
column14: “Are the lessors and the banks willing to still finance the MAX and buy the MAX? The answer to that right now is yes. And if that is the case that puts a floor on the value of the aircraft,” he said.
column15: He acknowledged banks may insist on lower loan-to-value ratios on loans issued against the MAX than against rival Airbus planes.
column16: Kelly said he would expect Boeing to compensate it if it is forced to take back leases and lease the plane to new airlines. Any costs due to the grounding or any fall in the planes value would also feed into talks on compensation, he said.
column17: “We would expect Boeing shareholders to absorb that pain because its their fault not our shareholders,” he said.

column4: Coronavirus set to impact Chinese airlines' first quarter profit: Aercap CEO
column5: DUBLIN (Reuters) - The chief executive of one of the world's largest aircraft lessors, Aercap AER.N, expects the new coronavirus that has emerged from Wuhan, China to impact Chinese airlines' profitability in the first quarter.
column6: Aengus Kelly said the outbreak was hitting traffic in the Chinese New Year when travel and yields peak but that past examples of the SARS and Ebola viruses show that if contained successfully, the impact on traffic will not be long-term.
column7: “There’s certainly going to be an impact on the profitability of Chinese airlines in the first quarter,” Kelly, whose customers include some of the world’s biggest airlines, told a conference in Dublin.

column4: AerCap CEO warns against panic discounts for Boeing 737 MAX jets
column5: DUBLIN (Reuters) - Owners of Boeing's BA.N grounded 737 MAX jet must keep cool heads and avoid offering panic discounts on sale or lease prices to avoid undermining its long-term value, the head of one of the world's largest aircraft lessors Aercap AER.N said on Monday.
column6: "Discipline and keeping a cool head is vital because if people panic and lease the airplane or sell the airplane at knock-down rates for an extended period of time, it will be harder for the residual value of that asset to recover," Aercap's AER.N Aengus Kelly told the Airline Economics aviation finance conference in Dublin.
column7: Aercap has 100 Boeing 737 MAX jets on order.
column8: “The brand is not in a great place right now and what we need to do is recover that brand operationally and then ... be absolutely disciplined when it comes to placing the aircraft,” Kelly said.
column9: (This story has been refiled to fix typographical error in headline)

column4: AerCap picks up Airbus jet orders dropped by Norwegian: sources
column5: PARIS (Reuters) - Orders for five unbuilt Airbus jets relinquished by budget carrier Norwegian Air NWC.OL this week are now under the ownership of leasing company AerCap AER.N as part of a deal to finance deposits on the planes, industry sources said.
column6: Airbus on Monday issued monthly data showing that the number of A320neos on order from Norwegian had fallen to 58 from 63.
column7: The five planes were also included in a separate tally of nine cancellations posted in September, Airbus data showed.
column8: They have now been transferred to AerCap, which reshuffled several of its Airbus orders in September, the sources said, adding the aircraft could be rented back to Norwegian.
column9: Norwegian Air said on Wednesday it had not reduced the number of aircraft it intends to take from Airbus AIR.PA.
column10: AerCap and Airbus declined to comment.
column11: Norwegian Air is Europe’s third-largest budget airline by passenger numbers after Ryanair and easyJet and has shaken up the market with cut-price transatlantic fares. But its rapid expansion has left it with hefty losses and high debt.
column12: Industry sources say Norwegian is now in talks with both Airbus and Boeing BA.N about restructuring future orders.

column4: Investment losses in AerCap push UAE's Waha into the red
column5: ABU DHABI, May 12 (Reuters) - Abu Dhabi-based investment firm Waha Capital on Sunday reported a first-quarter loss, hit by investment losses in AerCap.
column6: The firm made a net loss attributable to shareholders of 57.8 million dirhams ($15.8 million) in the three months ending March 31, compared to a net profit of 107.4 million dirhams in the prior-year period, it said in a statement
column7: Reuters reported last week that Abu Dhabi investment firm Gulf Capital and Waha Capital have held exploratory discussions regarding a merger, with talks having taken place over the last few months, sources told Reuters last week
column8: Waha said on Sunday it incurred a loss of 95 million dirhams on the disposal of shares in AerCap and 100 million dirhams towards reassessment of the value of AerCap’s recoverable amount, it said. Waha’s stake in AerCap stood at 10.3% at the end of March.
column9: In recent quarters, tough global market conditions have affected certain investments, and this has been reflected in the bottom line,” said Michael Raynes, chief executive of Waha.

column4: Greenlight's David Einhorn pitches long on AerCap, short on GATX at Sohn Conference
column5: (Reuters) - David Einhorn, president of Greenlight Capital, at the Sohn Investment Conference on Monday said his firm is positive on airplane leasing company AerCap Holdings and negative on railcar leasing company GATX Corp.
column6: Einhorn said GATX has “trouble returning to pre-crisis usage levels,” while AerCorp shares are trading at half the book value and less than half the price-to-earnings of GATX’s shares.
column7: Speaking favorably of both industries, he said the airline sector has some advantages over rail that make AerCap the better choice over GATX, whose shares he believes are overvalued. “Neither has consumer-facing businesses, and both have terrible news. AerCap operates in a growing industry with a favorable outlook,” Einhorn said. “We think the market has it wrong.”
column8: AerCap shares are up 31% in 2019, while GATX has gained 11% year-to-date.
column9: AerCap is the industry leader with 11% marketshare, he noted. As aircraft manufacturers Airbus and Boeing have backlogs of multiple years, aircraft leasing companies step in to fill the gap as air travel continues to increase around the globe.
column10: Einhorn, who told the Sohn Investment Conference that the theme of his pitch involved Trains, Planes and Automobiles, referencing a 1987 movie, reassured the audience that he still did not like Tesla Inc. Einhorn started out with a slide show of Tesla CEO Elon Musk’s statements about his electric car company and concluded by saying that’s “a lot of horseshit.”
column11: Einhorn has been short Tesla. In a letter to clients last month, Einhorn’s Greenlight renewed criticism of Musk and Tesla, saying the electric car company appeared to be “on the brink” of failure again.
column12: The letter cited a lack of demand, “desperate” price cuts, layoffs, “closing-and-then-not-closing” stores, closing service centers, slashing capital expenditures, rushed product announcements and “a new effort to distract investors from the demand problem with hyperbole over TSLA’s autonomous driving capabilities.”
column13: Tesla did not immediately respond to a request for comment on Einhorn’s remark.

column4: Greenlight's David Einhorn pitches long on AerCap, short on GATX at Sohn Conference
column5: May 6 (Reuters) - David Einhorn, president of Greenlight Capital, at the Sohn Investment Conference said his firm is positive on airplane leasing company AerCap Holdings and negative on railcar leasing company GATX Corp.
column6: Einhorn said GATX has “trouble returning to pre-crisis usage levels,” while AerCorp shares are trading at half the book value and less than half the price-to-earnings of GATX’s shares. (Reporting By Jennifer Ablan Editing by Chizu Nomiyama)
